column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-coal-idUSKBN12Z12W	Battered U.S. coal industry hopes for Trump
column2: prepares for Clinton	"

column1: By Timothy Gardner
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has won over the U.S. coal industry by promising to revive the downtrodden sector and scrap regulations if elected.     But the industry has a Plan B if the New York businessman loses to his more green-minded Democratic rival Hillary Clinton on Tuesday: carbon capture and storage
column2: a technology that captures carbon dioxide from burning coal and injects it underground
column3: where many scientists are optimistic it cannot contribute to global warming.Coal backers see CCS as a politically feasible solution that could help the next president thread the needle between environmentalists and a once-powerful business that is in desperate need of a lifeline. They have been pushing both major party candidates to embrace it.Staff at the National Enhanced Oil Recovery Initiative held separate teleconferences with the Clinton and Trump campaigns in August on the merits of a bill that would extend and raise tax breaks for coal and other fossil fuel companies doing CCS in oilfields
column4: from $10 per ton of carbon stored to $35 a ton. NEORI is made up of diverse groups ranging from environmental ogranizations to some of the country's largest coal companies.Weeks after the teleconference
column5: Clinton announced her support for the bipartisan CCS bill. Nearly 20 of 100 senators
column6: including Clinton's vice presidential running mate Tim Kaine
column7: also back it and expect it to gain momentum.     Trump has not given a position on the bill
column8: but a senior policy adviser to Trump's campaign
column10: said he ""supports all sources of American energy. This includes clean coal and research into new coal technologies.""

column1: My sense is Clinton recognizes that
column2: especially in certain parts of the country
column3: coal-based energy and other fossil fuels provide some of the highest-paying jobs in our economy
column4: said Brad Crabtree
column5: of the Great Plains Institute
column6: a policy group that pushes for the deployment technologies to reduce fossil fuel emissions
column7: and the parent organization of NEORI.Oil drillers have used CCS since the 1970s
column8: pumping carbon dioxide into aging reservoirs to force out remaining crude. Coal advocates want to expand CCS to coal-fueled power plants. But the business is expensive and needs incentives.TRUMP'S PLEDGE

column1: Trump's anti-regulation stance has made him a clear favorite of the industry
column2: because it suggests lower costs and risks for major producers like Arch Coal Inc
column3: Peabody Energy Corp
column4: Cloud Peak Energy Inc and Alpha Natural Resources Inc.The sector has given about $223
column5: 000 in support of Trump
column6: compared with none for Clinton
column7: according to a Reuters analysis of contributions over $200 made by several of the biggest coal companies and their employees.Coal faces a potentially starker future under Clinton. She has promised to build on Democratic President Barack Obama's disputed Clean Power Plan to curb carbon output and suffered political damage earlier this year when she said that by doing so ""we're going to put a lot of coal miners and coal companies out of business.""      Those jobs are already quickly evaporating.

column1: The industry now employs only about 65
column2: 000 miners across states like West Virginia
column3: Pennsylvania
column4: Kentucky and Wyoming
column5: down from around 91
column7: according to the most recent statistics from the U.S. Department of Energy. The country's top two biggest coal companies
column8: Arch and Peabody Energy
column9: this year filed for bankruptcy.Neither Trump scrapping federal regulations nor the expanded use of CCS will likely restore the sector
column10: where production last year dropped to the lowest level since 1986
column11: to its previous heights. Coal <NYM/QL> faces a dual headwind of both a global push for cleaner energy such as wind and solar power
column12: and drilling technology that has made its competitor natural gas abundant - and cheap.Jeff Holmstead
column13: a Republican lobbyist at Bracewell Law
column15: much of coal's fate in coming years could be determined in the first 30 to 60 days. By then it should be known whether she appoints staunch environmentalists at departments including the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of the Interior.But he is confident that Clinton would work with industry on CCS and allow ""coal to play a role in the future in the U.S. power sector.""     Elizabeth Gore
column16: a Democrat who lobbies with Brownstein
column18: Farber and Schreck for a coal-burning cooperative said coal companies must ""find the marginal changes they can make to buy themselves some time
column19: to provide more of a soft landing.""  (Reporting by Timothy Gardner; Additional reporting by Grant Smith
column20: Valerie Volcovici and Emily Stephenson; Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Lisa Shumaker)"	['Clinton'

column2: many big funds stay aggressive but cash tempts	"

column1: By Tim McLaughlin and Jamie McGeever
| BOSTON/LONDON
BOSTON/LONDON Stocks are listing
column2: bonds are drifting and suddenly gold is back in vogue. Global investors appear to be facing the prospect that next week's U.S. presidential election may not play out as they have been expecting.Until last Friday
column3: when the FBI said it had re-opened a probe of Democrat Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server while she was secretary of state
column4: the prevailing view among the investment set had her coasting to victory. And most investors have said in surveys they were more comfortable with that outcome than a victory by Republican Donald Trump.Now
column5: though
column6: several polls depict an ever-tightening race as the clock counts down to Election Day on Tuesday
column7: although the latest Reuters/Ipsos poll showed Clinton still with a 6-point lead.Investors generally see Clinton as a known quantity who would not make major changes that would upend financial markets
column8: while Trump's positions have been difficult to nail down.Yet against the tumultuous political backdrop
column9: some of the biggest American stock funds remain either too sanguine
column10: too confused or too focused on extending the bull market to guard against an Election Day result that could shock the world like the Brexit vote did in June.U.S. large-cap mutual funds
column12: are heading into the showdown for the White House with only a thin layer of cash to absorb any potential shocks from the stock market. Gerry Sullivan
column13: who runs USA Mutuals' $234 million Barrier Fund
column14: said it would be hard to reposition his portfolio even if he knew the election results ahead of time. ""There is so much confusion
column15: Sullivan said.U.S. funds that invest in stocks with large market capitalizations are not showing any drastic moves toward precaution. Overall
column16: they have only 3.1 percent of their assets dedicated to cash
column17: according to the latest data from Morningstar Inc. These same funds held more cash
column19: before Barack Obama defeated John McCain in 2008.Multi-asset investors are more defensively positioned
column20: especially those outside the United States
column21: according to the latest Reuters asset allocation poll. Funds in Europe held 8.1 percent of their portfolios in cash in late October
column22: while U.K.-based funds had some 9.6 percent of their holdings parked on the sidelines.

column1: Investors are holding higher-than-normal levels of cash
column2: said Mark Haefele
column3: global chief investment officer for UBS Wealth Management in London
column4: who oversees around $2 trillion in assets. ""That's one way of hedging the uncertainty.""Nonetheless
column5: Haefele said: ""We've not seen significant de-risking around the election
column6: but we have seen generally a consistent level of caution in the global client base.""With uncertainty about the outcome on the rise
column7: a risk-off mood has enveloped markets around the world. The S&P 500 index has declined for eight days in a row
column8: its longest losing streak since the market crash in October 2008
column9: while a benchmark for global stocks
column11: has dropped for seven of the last eight sessions. Both sit near four-month lows. Safe-haven bonds
column12: recently under pressure from expectations the U.S. Federal Reserve is on track to raise interest rates this year
column13: have seen only a modest boost in the meantime
column14: but gold has surged to a one-month high near $1

column1: The trades you're seeing in the market at the moment will go further in the event of a Trump victory
column2: said Mike Bell
column3: global market strategist at JP Morgan Asset Management in London. ""You'd expect more downside to U.S. equities
column4: the dollar and Treasury yields.""NOT AN ""INVESTABLE EVENT""

column1: More than half of the stock and bond fund managers polled by Northern Trust in the third quarter said they expected the election to cause a large increase in market volatility. Prices for certain S&P 500 index options expiring in the days after the election indicate a market swing of between 2 and 4 percent
column2: in either direction
column3: by then.Still
column4: portfolio managers sitting on a lot of cash
column5: some with more than 20 percent of assets
column6: say the stockpile is not a sign of worry about the outcome of the race.

column1: It's due to the diminished risk-reward profile of investment opportunities in a mature profit cycle
column2: said Meggan Walsh
column3: a portfolio manager at the $18 billion Invesco Diversified Dividend Fund. ""We do not feel the election is an investable event.""Some value-oriented large-cap fund managers say the stock market is over-valued and they are on high alert for a market correction as the election coincides with a bull market nearing completion of its eighth year. ""It can be tempting to forget that nasty downturns happen with some regularity
column4: and there is never a bell rung to announce their arrival
column5: portfolio managers Arik Ahitov and Dennis Bryant recently warned investors in the $800 million FPA Capital Fund. After Britain surprised the world with a vote to leave the European Union
column6: the S&P 500 Index tumbled nearly 4 percent on June 24. It soon recovered
column7: however
column8: and had regained record territory by mid-August.Even in Britain
column9: the referendum's unexpected outcome has yet to show it has long-lasting effects for investors outside of the currency market
column10: where the British pound has sunk to a three-decade low against the dollar. London's FTSE 100 index is up around 14-percent from its post-Brexit trough.The FPA Capital Fund managers had nearly 28 percent of the fund's $800 million in assets in cash during the third quarter. They see the stock market as too expensive and are ready for a high level of panic
column12: according to their October letter to investors.""An elevated level of forced selling
column13: combined with a lack of liquidity
column14: might result in challenges for many fully invested products such as index funds
column16: and funds that have no to very low levels of cash cushions
column17: the FPA Capital Fund portfolio managers said. ""In a down market
column18: cash helps mitigate losses and affords one the opportunity to buy when others are being forced to sell
column19: generally the best time to buy.""    (Reporting by Tim McLaughlin in Boston and Jamie McGeever in London; Editing by Dan Burns and Leslie Adler)"	['Clinton'

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKBN12Z009	Trump gains ground on Clinton: Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation	"
By Maurice Tamman
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK The race for the Oval Office tightened significantly in the past week
column2: as several swing states that Republican Donald Trump must win shifted from favoring Democrat Hillary Clinton to toss-ups
column3: according to the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project.The two presidential candidates are now tied in Florida and North Carolina
column4: and Clinton's lead in Michigan has narrowed so much that the state is too close to call. Ohio remains a dead heat and Pennsylvania is now tilting to Clinton.While Clinton remains the odds-on favorite to win Tuesday's election
column5: Trump now has a plausible route to victory
column6: especially if there is a sharp fall in turnout among African-Americans from the levels of the 2012 election.Still
column7: Trump must win both Florida and North Carolina to have a good chance of winning the White House. Clinton could lose both states and still win.The States of the Nation project estimates Clinton's odds of winning the needed 270 Electoral College votes at about 90 percent
column8: down from 95 percent last week. If the election had been held on Wednesday
column10: she would have had 256 solid electoral votes and an estimated final tally of about 302 votes
column12: she had 278 solid votes and a final tally of 320 votes
column15: Trump has had a good run in the past week. He has seen his support grow in 24 states while losing ground in 11. Conversely
column16: Clinton's support grew in 13 states while shrinking in 22.Trump's gains came in a period in which he had few new controversies to fend off
column17: while Clinton faced renewed scrutiny of her email practices.

column1: Most respondents to the latest survey were asked about their support for the candidates after FBI Director James Comey announced last Friday the agency was examining newly discovered emails that might pertain to Clinton's use of a private email server while she was secretary of state.Comey had concluded in July at the end of a year-long FBI probe of the email issue that there were no grounds to bring any charges against Clinton. His brief letter to Congress last week said the new trove of emails might or might not be significant.
Trump and other Republicans seized on the news to question Clinton's credibility
column2: while Democrats complained it could unfairly influence voters so close to the election.The States of the Nation project is a survey of about 15
column3: 000 people every week in all 50 states plus Washington
column4: D.C. State by state results are available by visiting here EARLY VOTING INDICATORS

column1: It is unclear if the FBI inquiry upset the balance in the race. But many national polls have found the race tightening in recent days. Polling averages last week showed Clinton with a lead of between 4 and 7 points. Those averages now show her lead at just 2 to 3 points. Last week
column2: the project had her leading 47 percent to 40 percent. This week
column3: it dropped to 45 percent to 42 percent.

column1: In the Reuters/Ipsos daily tracking poll from Oct. 28 to Nov. 1
column2: Clinton led Trump by 6 percentage points among likely voters
column3: the same margin as before the FBI announcement.There are other reasons for the Clinton campaign to worry. Among voters who have cast early ballots
column4: she leads Trump by about 8 points. At the same point in the 2012 race
column5: President Barack Obama had a lead of 11 points among early voters over Republican rival Mitt Romney. Obama's gap narrowed
column6: however
column7: to 6 points just before Election Day
column8: according to the States of the Nation project and separate Reuters/Ipsos polling.In Florida
column9: where the candidates are tied at 47 percent
column10: Clinton leads by 8 points among early voters. In 2012
column11: Obama led by about 15 points.In Ohio
column12: where the race also is tied
column13: she leads by about 20 points among early voters. At this point in 2012

column1: It is not clear why Clinton's early voting support has fallen short of Obama's. The shift could indicate a broader cross-section of voters is casting early ballots than in 2012. But the drop might also foreshadow lower-than-expected turnout among the core Democratic constituencies who propelled Obama to victory in 2008 and 2012.Clinton's success is built on holding together those blocs of voters. She does not
column2: for example
column3: enjoy the same support among African-Americans as Obama
column4: the first black U.S. president. Diminished support among blacks
column5: coupled with a large drop in black turnout
column6: would hurt the Democrat.If black Democratic turnout drops by 15 points nationally
column7: for example
column8: Clinton's odds of winning drop to about 72 percent
column9: by a projected margin of just 32 Electoral College votes. A drop of 20 points would reduce the odds of a Clinton victory to little more than a coin toss
column10: according to the project.Even a 10-point drop in black Democratic turnout coupled with a 5-point increase among white Republicans would flip the race to Trump
column11: the project found.The good news for Clinton is that about 60 percent of likely Hispanic voters are supporting her
column12: similar to the numbers Obama enjoyed in 2012. A 10-point increase in Hispanic turnout would go a long way toward offsetting a 10-point decrease in black turnout
column13: according to the project.The outlook is not all gloom for Clinton. She has made the race close in Arizona
column14: a longtime Republican stronghold. She has also regained the lead in Pennsylvania and is leading in Nevada.  (Editing by Michael Williams and Peter Cooney)"	['Clinton'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/uk-cricket-australia-hughes-idUSKBN12Z00J	Death of Australian Hughes ruled 'tragic accident'	"
By Colin Packham
| SYDNEY
SYDNEY The death of Australian batsman Phillip Hughes was a 'tragic accident' and not as a result of a failure to enforce the rules of the game or inadequate safety equipment
column2: the New South Wales (NSW) Coroner's Court ruled on Friday.Hughes was hit on the back of the neck by a rising delivery when playing for South Australia in a domestic match at the Sydney Cricket Ground on Nov. 25
column3: 2014. He died two days later in a Sydney hospital.After reviewing the circumstances surrounding the incident to determine whether the 25-year-old's death could have been avoided
column4: NSW State Coroner Michael Barnes said he could find no evidence to support the view of Hughes' family that he had died in a ""very unsafe workplace"".""The family's grief at losing their much loved son and brother was exacerbated by their belief that unfair play had contributed to his death
column5: said Barnes.""It is hoped that they accept the compelling evidence that the rules were complied with. Phillip was excelling at the crease as he so often did and that his death was a tragic accident.""

column1: The helmet worn by Hughes came under the spotlight following his death
column2: though the NSW Coroner said the batsman's death could not have been avoided by wearing different protective equipment. Australia's cricket board in May made it compulsory for players to wear helmets when facing fast and medium-paced bowling in line with recommendations from a review into the death of Hughes.

column1: The family had been angered that Hughes had been subjected to threatening language from an opponent and had suffered a sustained spell of aggressive short-pitched bowling that contravened the rules of the game.    Barnes accepted Hughes had received a barrage of short-pitch blowing
column2: but all of which fell within the rules of the game.The court said it was unable to rule on whether Hughes had been subjected to threatening language
column3: though Barnes said it was implausible that no ""sledging"" had occurred at all during the day.

column1: Hopefully
column2: the focus on this unsavoury aspect of the incident may cause those who claim to love the game to reflect upon whether the practice of sledging is worthy of its participants
column3: said Barnes. ""An outsider is left to wonder why such a beautiful game would need such an ugly underside."" (Editing by Peter Rutherford)"	[]	[]

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ryan-idUSKBN12Y2WM	U.S. House Speaker Ryan running for re-election: spokeswoman	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan is running again for the job in the next Congress
column2: a spokeswoman said on Thursday after a media report quoted several unidentified House Republicans as saying they expected him to step down next week.""He is running
column3: Ryan spokeswoman AshLee Strong said.The Hill cited four House Republicans as saying that they expected Ryan to step aside as Speaker after next Tuesday's general election.""Speculation is growing that Paul will not return
column4: the Hill quoted a ""senior GOP lawmaker close to leadership"" as saying.

column1: It quoted a member of the Freedom Caucus
column2: a group of conservative Republicans
column3: as saying that if Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton wins
column4: Ryan will get ""a good share of the blame"" among House members who support Republican candidate Donald Trump.Ryan last month told fellow Republicans that he would not defend or campaign for Trump and would instead focus on re-electing Republicans to keep the majority in the House.

column1: This angered some Trump supporters in the House
column2: who felt the Wisconsin congressman should stand by Trump. One of them
column3: Representative Jim Bridenstine of Oklahoma
column4: tweeted: ""if Paul Ryan isn't for Trump
column5: then I'm not for Paul Ryan.""But Ryan
column6: who as Speaker is the country's highest-ranking Republican
column7: has a great deal of support in the Republican caucus
column8: and it is far from clear that his critics would be able to oust him if they tried.

column1: House Republicans
column2: who currently number 246
column3: plan to have closed-door leadership elections in mid-November. Ryan is expected to win their nomination for Speaker at that gathering
column4: but the actual election to the Speaker's post would not be held until the new Congress convenes in January.All members of the House
column5: both Republican and Democrat
column6: will vote in the Speaker election and Ryan will need 218 votes - a majority of the House's 435 members - to win. This could be a challenge if Republicans lose a substantial number of seats in next week's elections
column7: and if some of those who remain decide to oppose Ryan. (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; editing by Grant McCool)"	['Bridenstine'
